verses.verse: (5 Elihu accuseth Job of ignorance.14 He showeth that God hath divers means to instruct man and to draw him from sin.19, 29 He afflicteth man and suddenly delivereth him.26 Man being delivered giveth thanks to God.) Wherefore, Job, I pray thee, hear my talk, and hearken unto all my words.
Behold now, I have opened my mouth: my tongue hath spoken in my mouth.
My words are in the uprightness of mine heart, and my lips shall speak pure knowledge.
The (I confess the power of God, and am one of his, therefore thou oughtest to hear me.) Spirit of God hath made me, and the breath of the Almighty hath given me life.
If thou canst give me answer, prepare thyself and stand before me.

Behold, I am according to thy wish in (Because Job had wished to dispute his cause with God, Job 16:21, so that he might do it without fear, Elihu saith, he will reason in God’s stead, whom he needeth not to fear, because he is a man made of the same matter that he is.) God’s stead: I am also formed of the clay.
Behold, my terror shall not fear thee, neither shall mine hand (I will not handle thee so roughly as these others have done.) be heavy upon thee.
Doubtless thou hast spoken in mine ears, and I have heard the voice of thy words.
I am (He repeateth Job’s words, whereby he protested his innocence in divers places, but specially in Job 13, 16 and 30.) clean, without sin: I am innocent and there is none iniquity in me.
Lo, he hath found occasions against me, and counted me for his enemy.
He hath put my feet in the stocks, and looketh narrowly unto all my paths.
Behold, in this hast thou not done right: I will answer thee, that God is greater than man.
Why dost thou strive against him? for he doth not (The cause of his judgments is not always declared to man.) give account of all his matters.

For God speaketh (Though God by sundry examples of his judgments speak unto man, yet the reason thereof is not known: yea and though God should speak, yet is he not understood.) once or twice, and one seeth it not.

In dreams and (God saith he, speaketh commonly, either by visions to teach us the cause of his judgments, or else by afflictions, or by his messenger.) visions of the night, when sleep falleth upon men, and they sleep upon their beds,
Then he openeth the ears of men, even by their corrections, which he (That is, determined to send upon them.) had sealed,
That he might cause man to turn away from his enterprise, and that he might hide the (He showeth for what end God sendeth afflictions: to beat down man’s pride, and to turn from evil.) pride of man,
And keep back his soul from the pit, and that his life should not pass by the sword.
He is also stricken with sorrow upon his bed, and the grief of his bones is sore,
So that his (That is, his painful and miserable life.) life causeth him to abhor bread, and his soul dainty meat.
His flesh faileth that it cannot be seen, and his bones which were not seen, clatter.
So his soul draweth to the grave, and his life (To them that shall bury him.) to the buriers.

If there be a (A man sent of God to declare his will.) messenger with him, or an interpreter, one of a thousand (A singular man, and as one chosen out of a thousand, which is able to declare the great mercies of God unto sinners: and wherein man’s righteousness standeth, which is through the justice of Jesus Christ and faith therein.) to declare unto man his righteousness,

Then will he have (He showeth that it is a sure token of God’s mercy toward sinners, when he causeth his word to be preached unto them.) mercy upon him, and will say, (That is, the minister shall by the preaching of the word pronounce unto him the forgiveness of his sins.) Deliver him, that he go not down into the pit: for I have received a reconciliation.

Then shall his flesh be (He shall feel God’s favor and rejoice: declaring hereby wherein standeth the true joy of the faithful, and that God will restore him to health of body, which is a token of his blessing.) as fresh as a child’s, and shall return as in the days of his youth.
He shall pray unto God, and he will be favorable unto him, and he shall see his face with joy: for he will render unto man his (God will forgive his sins, and accept him as just.) righteousness.
He looketh upon men, and if one say, I have sinned, and (That is, done wickedly.) perverted righteousness, and it did not profit (But my sins hath been the cause of God’s wrath toward me.) me,
(God will forgive the penitent sinner.) He will deliver his soul from going into the pit, and his life shall see the light.
Lo, all these things will God work (Meaning, oftentimes, even as oft as a sinner doth repent.) twice or thrice with a man,
That he may turn back his soul from the pit, to be illuminated in the light of the living.
Mark well, O Job, and hear me: keep silence and I will speak.

If there be (If thou doubt of anything, or see occasion to speak against it.) matter, answer me, and speak: for I desire to (That is, to show thee, wherein man’s justification consisteth.) justify thee.
If thou hast not, hear me: hold thy tongue, and I will teach thee wisdom.
